00141|     or little endian. Some editors or libraries may prepend a BOM.

00148|     if head[:3] == codecs.BOM_UTF8:
00149|         return "utf-8-sig"

00151|     if b"\x00" not in head:
00152|         return "utf-8"
00153| 
00154|     if head in (codecs.BOM_UTF32_BE, codecs.BOM_UTF32_LE):
00155|         return "utf-32"
00156| 
00157|     if head[:2] in (codecs.BOM_UTF16_BE, codecs.BOM_UTF16_LE):
00158|         return "utf-16"

00160|     if len(head) == 4:

00162|             return "utf-32-be"

00164|         if head[::2] == b"\x00\x00":

00170|         if head[1::2] == b"\x00\x00":

00174|         return "utf-16-be" if head.startswith(b"\x00") else "utf-16-le"

00296| def jsonify(*args, **kwargs):
00297|     """This function wraps :func:`dumps` to add a few enhancements that make
00298|     life easier.  It turns the JSON output into a :class:`~flask.Response`
00299|     object with the :mimetype:`application/json` mimetype.  For convenience, it
00300|     also converts multiple arguments into an array or multiple keyword arguments
00301|     into a dict.  This means that both ``jsonify(1,2,3)`` and
00302|     ``jsonify([1,2,3])`` serialize to ``[1,2,3]``.
00303| 
00304|     For clarity, the JSON serialization behavior has the following differences
00305|     from :func:`dumps`:
00306| 
00307|     1. Single argument: Passed straight through to :func:`dumps`.
00308|     2. Multiple arguments: Converted to an array before being passed to
00309|        :func:`dumps`.
00310|     3. Multiple keyword arguments: Converted to a dict before being passed to
00311|        :func:`dumps`.
00312|     4. Both args and kwargs: Behavior undefined and will throw an exception.
00313| 
00314|     Example usage::
00315| 
00316|         from flask import jsonify
00317| 
00318|         @app.route('/_get_current_user')
00319|         def get_current_user():
00320|             return jsonify(username=g.user.username,
00321|                            email=g.user.email,
00322|                            id=g.user.id)
00323|

00325| 
00326|         {
00327|             "username": "admin",
00328|             "email": "admin@localhost",
00329|             "id": 42
00330|         }
00331| 
00332| 
00333|     .. versionchanged:: 0.11
00334|         Added support for serializing top-level arrays. This introduces
00335|         a security risk in ancient browsers. See :ref:`security-json`
00336|         for details.
00337| 
00338|     This function's response will be pretty printed if the
00339|     ``JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR`` config parameter is set to True or the
00340|     Flask app is running in debug mode. Compressed (not pretty) formatting
00341|     currently means no indents and no spaces after separators.
00342| 
00343|     .. versionadded:: 0.2
00344|     """
00345| 
00346|     indent = None
00347|     separators = (",", ":")
00348| 
00349|     if current_app.config["JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR"] or current_app.debug:
00350|         indent = 2
00351|         separators = (", ", ": ")

00353|     if args and kwargs:
00354|         raise TypeError("jsonify() behavior undefined when passed both args and kwargs")

00356|         data = args[0]

00361|         f"{dumps(data, indent=indent, separators=separators)}\n",
00362|         mimetype=current_app.config["JSONIFY_MIMETYPE"],

00282| JSON Support
00283| ------------
00284| 
00285| .. module:: flask.json
00286| 
00287| Flask uses ``simplejson`` for the JSON implementation.  Since simplejson
00288| is provided by both the standard library as well as extension, Flask will
00289| try simplejson first and then fall back to the stdlib json module.  On top
00290| of that it will delegate access to the current application's JSON encoders
00291| and decoders for easier customization.
00292| 
00293| So for starters instead of doing::
00294| 
00295|     try:
00296|         import simplejson as json
00297|     except ImportError:
00298|         import json
00299| 
00300| You can instead just do this::
00301| 
00302|     from flask import json
00303| 
00304| For usage examples, read the :mod:`json` documentation in the standard
00305| library.  The following extensions are by default applied to the stdlib's
00306| JSON module:
00307| 
00308| 1.  ``datetime`` objects are serialized as :rfc:`822` strings.
00309| 2.  Any object with an ``__html__`` method (like :class:`~flask.Markup`)
00310|     will have that method called and then the return value is serialized
00311|     as string.
00312| 
00313| The :func:`~htmlsafe_dumps` function of this json module is also available
00314| as a filter called ``|tojson`` in Jinja2.  Note that in versions of Flask prior
00315| to Flask 0.10, you must disable escaping with ``|safe`` if you intend to use
00316| ``|tojson`` output inside ``script`` tags. In Flask 0.10 and above, this
00317| happens automatically (but it's harmless to include ``|safe`` anyway).
00318| 
00319| .. sourcecode:: html+jinja
00320| 
00321|     <script type=text/javascript>
00322|         doSomethingWith({{ user.username|tojson|safe }});
00323|     </script>
00324| 
00325| .. admonition:: Auto-Sort JSON Keys
00326| 
00327|     The configuration variable :data:`JSON_SORT_KEYS` can be set to
00328|     ``False`` to stop Flask from auto-sorting keys. By default sorting
00329|     is enabled and outside of the app context sorting is turned on.
00330| 
00331|     Notice that disabling key sorting can cause issues when using
00332|     content  based HTTP caches and Python's hash randomization feature.
00333|

00003| 
00004| 
00005| Python Version
00006| --------------
00007| 
00008| We recommend using the latest version of Python. Flask supports Python
00009| 3.6 and newer.
00010| 
00011| 
00012| Dependencies
00013| ------------
00014| 
00015| These distributions will be installed automatically when installing Flask.
00016| 
00017| * `Werkzeug`_ implements WSGI, the standard Python interface between
00018|   applications and servers.
00019| * `Jinja`_ is a template language that renders the pages your application
00020|   serves.
00021| * `MarkupSafe`_ comes with Jinja. It escapes untrusted input when rendering
00022|   templates to avoid injection attacks.
00023| * `ItsDangerous`_ securely signs data to ensure its integrity. This is used
00024|   to protect Flask's session cookie.
00025| * `Click`_ is a framework for writing command line applications. It provides
00026|   the ``flask`` command and allows adding custom management commands.
00027| 
00028| .. _Werkzeug: https://palletsprojects.com/p/werkzeug/
00029| .. _Jinja: https://palletsprojects.com/p/jinja/
00030| .. _MarkupSafe: https://palletsprojects.com/p/markupsafe/
00031| .. _ItsDangerous: https://palletsprojects.com/p/itsdangerous/
00032| .. _Click: https://palletsprojects.com/p/click/
00033| 
00034| 
00035| Optional dependencies
00036| ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00037| 
00038| These distributions will not be installed automatically. Flask will detect and
00039| use them if you install them.
00040| 
00041| * `Blinker`_ provides support for :doc:`signals`.
00042| * `SimpleJSON`_ is a fast JSON implementation that is compatible with
00043|   Python's ``json`` module. It is preferred for JSON operations if it is
00044|   installed.
00045| * `python-dotenv`_ enables support for :ref:`dotenv` when running ``flask``
00046|   commands.
00047| * `Watchdog`_ provides a faster, more efficient reloader for the development
00048|   server.
00049| 
00050| .. _Blinker: https://pythonhosted.org/blinker/
00051| .. _SimpleJSON: https://simplejson.readthedocs.io/
00052| .. _python-dotenv: https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv#readme
00053| .. _watchdog: https://pythonhosted.org/watchdog/
00054| 
00055| 
00056| Virtual environments
00057| --------------------
00058| 
00059| Use a virtual environment to manage the dependencies for your project, both in
00060| development and in production.
00061| 
00062| What problem does a virtual environment solve? The more Python projects you
00063| have, the more likely it is that you need to work with different versions of
00064| Python libraries, or even Python itself. Newer versions of libraries for one
00065| project can break compatibility in another project.
00066| 
00067| Virtual environments are independent groups of Python libraries, one for each
00068| project. Packages installed for one project will not affect other projects or
00069| the operating system's packages.
00070| 
00071| Python comes bundled with the :mod:`venv` module to create virtual
00072| environments.
00073| 
00074| 
00075| .. _install-create-env:
00076| 
00077| Create an environment
00078| ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00079| 
00080| Create a project folder and a :file:`venv` folder within:
00081| 
00082| .. code-block:: sh
00083| 
00084|     $ mkdir myproject
00085|     $ cd myproject
00086|     $ python3 -m venv venv
00087| 
00088| On Windows:
00089| 
00090| .. code-block:: bat
00091| 
00092|     $ py -3 -m venv venv
00093| 
00094| 
00095| .. _install-activate-env:
00096| 
00097| Activate the environment
00098| ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00099| 
00100| Before you work on your project, activate the corresponding environment:
00101| 
00102| .. code-block:: sh
00103| 
00104|     $ . venv/bin/activate
00105| 
00106| On Windows:
00107| 
00108| .. code-block:: bat
00109| 
00110|     > venv\Scripts\activate
00111| 
00112| Your shell prompt will change to show the name of the activated
00113| environment.
00114| 
00115|

00559|     broke compatibility with the common case of people putting binary
00560|     data for token verification into the session.
00561| -   Fixed an issue where registering the same method twice for the same
00562|     endpoint would trigger an exception incorrectly.
00563| 
00564| 
00565| Version 0.10
00566| ------------
00567| 
00568| Released 2013-06-13, codename Limoncello
00569| 
00570| -   Changed default cookie serialization format from pickle to JSON to
00571|     limit the impact an attacker can do if the secret key leaks.
00572| -   Added ``template_test`` methods in addition to the already existing
00573|     ``template_filter`` method family.
00574| -   Added ``template_global`` methods in addition to the already
00575|     existing ``template_filter`` method family.
00576| -   Set the content-length header for x-sendfile.
00577| -   ``tojson`` filter now does not escape script blocks in HTML5
00578|     parsers.
00579| -   ``tojson`` used in templates is now safe by default due. This was
00580|     allowed due to the different escaping behavior.
00581| -   Flask will now raise an error if you attempt to register a new
00582|     function on an already used endpoint.
00583| -   Added wrapper module around simplejson and added default
00584|     serialization of datetime objects. This allows much easier
00585|     customization of how JSON is handled by Flask or any Flask
00586|     extension.
00587| -   Removed deprecated internal ``flask.session`` module alias. Use
00588|     ``flask.sessions`` instead to get the session module. This is not to
00589|     be confused with ``flask.session`` the session proxy.
00590| -   Templates can now be rendered without request context. The behavior
00591|     is slightly different as the ``request``, ``session`` and ``g``
00592|     objects will not be available and blueprint's context processors are
00593|     not called.
00594| -   The config object is now available to the template as a real global
00595|     and not through a context processor which makes it available even in
00596|     imported templates by default.
00597| -   Added an option to generate non-ascii encoded JSON which should
00598|     result in less bytes being transmitted over the network. It's
00599|     disabled by default to not cause confusion with existing libraries
00600|     that might expect ``flask.json.dumps`` to return bytes by default.
00601| -   ``flask.g`` is now stored on the app context instead of the request
00602|     context.
00603| -   ``flask.g`` now gained a ``get()`` method for not erroring out on
00604|     non existing items.
00605| -   ``flask.g`` now can be used with the ``in`` operator to see what's
00606|     defined and it now is iterable and will yield all attributes stored.
00607| -   ``flask.Flask.request_globals_class`` got renamed to
00608|     ``flask.Flask.app_ctx_globals_class`` which is a better name to what
00609|     it does since 0.10.
00610| -   ``request``, ``session`` and ``g`` are now also added as proxies to
00611|     the template context which makes them available in imported
00612|     templates. One has to be very careful with those though because
00613|     usage outside of macros might cause caching.
00614| -   Flask will no longer invoke the wrong error handlers if a proxy
00615|     exception is passed through.
00616| -   Added a workaround for chrome's cookies in localhost not working as
00617|     intended with domain names.
00618| -   Changed logic for picking defaults for cookie values from sessions
00619|     to work better with Google Chrome.
00620| -   Added ``message_flashed`` signal that simplifies flashing testing.
00621| -   Added support for copying of request contexts for better working
00622|     with greenlets.
00623| -   Removed custom JSON HTTP exception subclasses. If you were relying
00624|     on them you can reintroduce them again yourself trivially. Using
00625|     them however is strongly discouraged as the interface was flawed.
00626| -   Python requirements changed: requiring Python 2.6 or 2.7 now to
00627|     prepare for Python 3.3 port.
00628| -   Changed how the teardown system is informed about exceptions. This
00629|     is now more reliable in case something handles an exception halfway
00630|     through the error handling process.

00002| Tagged JSON
00003| ~~~~~~~~~~~
00004| 
00005| A compact representation for lossless serialization of non-standard JSON
00006| types. :class:`~flask.sessions.SecureCookieSessionInterface` uses this
00007| to serialize the session data, but it may be useful in other places. It
00008| can be extended to support other types.
00009| 
00010| .. autoclass:: TaggedJSONSerializer
00011|     :members:
00012| 
00013| .. autoclass:: JSONTag
00014|     :members:
00015| 
00016| Let's see an example that adds support for
00017| :class:`~collections.OrderedDict`. Dicts don't have an order in JSON, so
00018| to handle this we will dump the items as a list of ``[key, value]``
00019| pairs. Subclass :class:`JSONTag` and give it the new key ``' od'`` to
00020| identify the type. The session serializer processes dicts first, so
00021| insert the new tag at the front of the order since ``OrderedDict`` must
00022| be processed before ``dict``.
00023| 
00024| .. code-block:: python
00025| 
00026|     from flask.json.tag import JSONTag
00027| 
00028|     class TagOrderedDict(JSONTag):
00029|         __slots__ = ('serializer',)
00030|         key = ' od'
00031| 
00032|         def check(self, value):
00033|             return isinstance(value, OrderedDict)
00034| 
00035|         def to_json(self, value):
00036|             return [[k, self.serializer.tag(v)] for k, v in iteritems(value)]
00037| 
00038|         def to_python(self, value):
00039|             return OrderedDict(value)
00040| 
00041|     app.session_interface.serializer.register(TagOrderedDict, index=0)
00042| """

00056| class JSONTag:
00057|     """Base class for defining type tags for :class:`TaggedJSONSerializer`."""
00058| 
00059|     __slots__ = ("serializer",)
00060| 
00061|     #: The tag to mark the serialized object with. If ``None``, this tag is
00062|     #: only used as an intermediate step during tagging.
00063|     key = None
00064| 
00065|     def __init__(self, serializer):
00066|         """Create a tagger for the given serializer."""
00067|         self.serializer = serializer
00068| 
00069|     def check(self, value):
00070|         """Check if the given value should be tagged by this tag."""
00071|         raise NotImplementedError
00072| 
00073|     def to_json(self, value):
00074|         """Convert the Python object to an object that is a valid JSON type.
00075|         The tag will be added later."""
00076|         raise NotImplementedError
00077| 
00078|     def to_python(self, value):
00079|         """Convert the JSON representation back to the correct type. The tag
00080|         will already be removed."""
00081|         raise NotImplementedError
00082| 
00083|     def tag(self, value):
00084|         """Convert the value to a valid JSON type and add the tag structure
00085|         around it."""
00086|         return {self.key: self.to_json(value)}

00089| class TagDict(JSONTag):
00090|     """Tag for 1-item dicts whose only key matches a registered tag.
00091| 
00092|     Internally, the dict key is suffixed with `__`, and the suffix is removed
00093|     when deserializing.

00095| 
00096|     __slots__ = ()
00097|     key = " di"
00098| 
00099|     def check(self, value):
00100|         return (
00101|             isinstance(value, dict)
00102|             and len(value) == 1
00103|             and next(iter(value)) in self.serializer.tags
00104|         )
00105| 
00106|     def to_json(self, value):
00107|         key = next(iter(value))
00108|         return {f"{key}__": self.serializer.tag(value[key])}
00109| 
00110|     def to_python(self, value):
00111|         key = next(iter(value))
00112|         return {key[:-2]: value[key]}

00215| class TaggedJSONSerializer:
00216|     """Serializer that uses a tag system to compactly represent objects that
00217|     are not JSON types. Passed as the intermediate serializer to
00218|     :class:`itsdangerous.Serializer`.
00219| 
00220|     The following extra types are supported:
00221| 
00222|     * :class:`dict`
00223|     * :class:`tuple`
00224|     * :class:`bytes`
00225|     * :class:`~flask.Markup`
00226|     * :class:`~uuid.UUID`
00227|     * :class:`~datetime.datetime`
00228|     """
00229| 
00230|     __slots__ = ("tags", "order")
00231| 
00232|     #: Tag classes to bind when creating the serializer. Other tags can be
00233|     #: added later using :meth:`~register`.
00234|     default_tags = [
00235|         TagDict,
00236|         PassDict,
00237|         TagTuple,
00238|         PassList,
00239|         TagBytes,
00240|         TagMarkup,
00241|         TagUUID,
00242|         TagDateTime,
00243|     ]
00244| 
00245|     def __init__(self):
00246|         self.tags = {}
00247|         self.order = []
00248| 
00249|         for cls in self.default_tags:
00250|             self.register(cls)
00251| 
00252|     def register(self, tag_class, force=False, index=None):
00253|         """Register a new tag with this serializer.
00254| 
00255|         :param tag_class: tag class to register. Will be instantiated with this
00256|             serializer instance.
00257|         :param force: overwrite an existing tag. If false (default), a
00258|             :exc:`KeyError` is raised.
00259|         :param index: index to insert the new tag in the tag order. Useful when
00260|             the new tag is a special case of an existing tag. If ``None``
00261|             (default), the tag is appended to the end of the order.
00262| 
00263|         :raise KeyError: if the tag key is already registered and ``force`` is
00264|             not true.
00265|         """
00266|         tag = tag_class(self)
00267|         key = tag.key
00268| 
00269|         if key is not None:
00270|             if not force and key in self.tags:
00271|                 raise KeyError(f"Tag '{key}' is already registered.")
00272| 
00273|             self.tags[key] = tag
00274| 
00275|         if index is None:
00276|             self.order.append(tag)
00277|         else:
00278|             self.order.insert(index, tag)
00279| 
00280|     def tag(self, value):
00281|         """Convert a value to a tagged representation if necessary."""
00282|         for tag in self.order:
00283|             if tag.check(value):
00284|                 return tag.tag(value)
00285| 
00286|         return value
00287| 
00288|     def untag(self, value):
00289|         """Convert a tagged representation back to the original type."""
00290|         if len(value) != 1:
00291|             return value
00292| 
00293|         key = next(iter(value))
00294| 
00295|         if key not in self.tags:
00296|             return value
00297| 
00298|         return self.tags[key].to_python(value[key])
00299| 
00300|     def dumps(self, value):
00301|         """Tag the value and dump it to a compact JSON string."""
00302|         return dumps(self.tag(value), separators=(",", ":"))
00303| 
00304|     def loads(self, value):
00305|         """Load data from a JSON string and deserialized any tagged objects."""
00306|         return loads(value, object_hook=self.untag)
